instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up
threads.message:
Original issue was GPU panic fault causing image to suddenly stop feeding to the display. The customer tried desoldering the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> but ended up bridging a couple pins and yanking off a couple resistors and capacitors. During which the GPU ended up getting fried, resistance measurements of PP1V5R1V35_GPU_REG was reading short. Pulled GPU and short is missing. 

Currently i have <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and GPU pulled, but whenever i apply power to the board, i keep popping <CAPACITOR>C8963</CAPACITOR>. Confirmed no short is present. Once i replace the capacitor, i get a resistance reading of about 18k ohms. Is the keeping the GPU and <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> out of the circuit the reason for <CAPACITOR>C8963</CAPACITOR> popping?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up
threads.message:
Really bad idea to power up the board without <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>.
You left <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> Gate terminals floating on the air!
At least one high side MOSFET is shorted now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up
